results.title: ACMI Presents: A Life Exposed: Robyn Beeche
results.brief_description: The 2013 documentary “A Life Exposed” (directed by Lesley Branagan) explores the life and work of Australian photographer Robyn Beeche. In this ACMI event, writer and former editor of Vogue Australia, Kirstie Clements, leads a discussion between Beeche and Branagan.

results.title: Cookery Nook [advertisement]
results.creator_credit: Australian Dried Fruits Association and Australian Sound Films
results.brief_description: A surreal slice of life from the 1930s, this advertisement was possibly the second sound cartoon ever made in Australia (an advertisement for Shell Oil, Percy Perplexed, being the first). Both films were made by the same production house, Melbourne’s Australian Sound Films, and animator, Dick Ovenden. His work as an illustrator was well known to Australians through his work in newspapers and magazines. Both Percy Perplexed and Cookery Nook were produced at a time when sound films were changing the face of cinema. ‘Cookery Nook’ may have been screened in the Dried Fruits van that toured the country promoting dried fruits to community and mothers’ groups. In a newspaper article from the same year, JM Balfour, Chair of the publicity committee, emphasised ‘the desirability, both in the interests of health and for the sake of hundreds of growers, that more raisins and sultanas should be used in Australia” (see also: The Sydney Morning Herald, 8 July 1931). [Source: Beth Taylor and Sally Jackson.]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Dried Fruits Association and Australian Sound Films

results.title: The Telegram Man
results.creator_credit: Victoria Wharfe McIntyre, Ceinwen Berry and James Khehtie
results.brief_description: Multi-award-winning film ‘The Telegram Man’ poignantly depicts the human cost of war in its portrayal of relationships impacted by the vicissitudes of wartime. Featuring restrained but deeply emotional performances from some of Australia’s finest screen actors (Jack Thompson, Gary Sweet and Sigrid Thornton), this is a powerful film about loss, grief and duty.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria Wharfe McIntyre, Ceinwen Berry and James Khehtie

results.title: An Interview with Gillian Armstrong
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Award-winning Australian film and documentary director Gillian Armstrong’s film career spans over 40 years locally and internationally.

Here she shares her discovery of Orry-Kelly and the incredibly fortunate set of events that uncovered his memoir and his box of memorabilia including his three Oscars.

The release of Armstrong’s 2015 feature-length documentary on the life and work of renowned costume designer Orry-Kelly, ‘Women He’s Undressed’, coincided with ACMI’s exhibition ‘Orry-Kelly: Dressing Hollywood’.

results.title: An Interview with Peter Clemence
results.brief_description: Peter Clemence tells us his experience in the Royal Australian Air Force at the end of the Second World War, his experiences flying scientists in Antarctica in the 1950’s and his adventures flying helicopters during the mining exploration era. He also talks about Ash Wednesday and the collapse of the West Gate Bridge.

results.title: Bring out a Briton
results.brief_description:
“Form a committee in your district and… Bring Out A Briton”. Chips Rafferty is called upon to promote the Department of Immigration’s campaign to encourage sponsored British migration to Australia.
Launched in 1957, the program urged towns across Australia to form committees to organise employment opportunities and accommodation for incoming British migrants.

results.title: Zembla
results.creator_credit: Katrina Salvadore and St Columba's College
results.brief_description: Zembla is a word derived from “zemblanity”, a term coined by the British author William Boyd to mean “the opposite of serendipity”.

results.title: Loose Change
results.brief_description: ‘Loose Change’ is a short animated film about money and demonstrates what you can do with money. The film has various coins and dollars talking and discussing what it is like being money.
